data.title: Improve task API and adopt gulp extension to it.
workspaceRoot invalid on Git Bash and WSL
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set default shell to Git Bash or WSL (CTRL+SHIFT+P - "shell")
2. Run a launch task using `${workspaceRoot}`

Here's an example launch config:

```json
{
  "name": "Debug All (node2)",
  "type": "node2",
  "request": "launch",
  "protocol": "inspector",
  "stopOnEntry": false,
  "args": [
    "--nolazy",
    "${workspaceRoot}/debugall.js"
  ],
  "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}/",
  "preLaunchTask": null,
  "runtimeExecutable": null,
  "env": {
    "NODE_ENV": "development"
  },
  "sourceMaps": false,
  "outDir": null,
  "console": "integratedTerminal",
  "skipFiles": [
    "<node_internals>/**",
    "**/node_modules/**"
  ]
},
```

Running this with the Powershell terminal works just fine. When running in WSL or Git Bash, the `${workspaceRoot}` uses backslashes in the path and fails:

```sh
$ cd c:\dev\projectname/ ; env NODE_ENV=development node --inspect=32931
 --debug-brk --nolazy c:\dev\projectname/debugall.js
bash: cd: c:projectname/: No such file or directory
Debugger listening on port 32931.
Warning: This is an experimental feature and could change at any time.
To start debugging, open the following URL in Chrome:
    chrome-devtools://devtools/remote/serve_file/@60cd6e859b9f557d2312f5bf532f6aec5f284980/inspector.html?experiments=true&v8only=true&ws=localhost:32931/afb2c
73f-e645-4693-91bf-fc4b5a6364f8
Debugger attached.
module.js:471
    throw err;
    ^

Error: Cannot find module 'c:\dev\projectname\devprojectname\debugall.js'
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (module.js:469:15)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:417:25)
    at Timeout.Module.runMain [as _onTimeout] (module.js:604:10)
    at ontimeout (timers.js:365:14)
    at tryOnTimeout (timers.js:237:5)
    at Timer.listOnTimeout (timers.js:207:5)
Waiting for the debugger to disconnect...
```

Note that these commands will work in Git Bash if the backslashes are converted to the proper forward-slashes:

```sh
$ cd c:\dev\projectname
bash: cd: c:devprojectname: No such file or directory
$ cd c:/dev/projectname
[no error]
$ node c:/dev/projectname/debugall.js
[runs without error]
```

Converting the slashes doesn't fix WSL, though. In Git Bash the drives are mounted like `/c/` for `c:\`. In WSL they're mounted at `/mnt/c/`, so it may require changing the drive part of `${workspaceRoot}` depending on the shell you have selected. We could hard-code the workspace root, but that forces everyone to use a *nix based shell and have the project in the same path on their different machines.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.0
- OS Version: Sierra 10.12

hi, this is not an issue, but do you have any plan to find a way for syncing vscode in user devices, one user have multiple devices... i have a macbook pro, a pc with windows os, a vps with windows server... i see theme, i like it and then i install it in my mac... but other devices does not know anything about this installation... if there was a way to syncing all vscode extensions, it was very helpful...

data.title: Enhancement Request: Need markdown preview support MathJax
Update prompts are too aggressive
data.body:
Update prompts right now are pretty aggressive with "Update now" or "later".
"Later" being next time you start it which is incredibly irritating.

Why?

Because VSCode being JS seems unable to maintain any API compatibility with extensions every other release which is a nightmare for those who actually depend on extensions. And extensions authors don't necessarily get to updating extensions for awhile.

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Win10


The 1.11 update broke a slew of extensions due what I am guessing is DOM changes somewhere.


There should be a way of saying "Go away, I don't want this automatic prompt" and then you can manually trigger it from the menu when you finally want to update.

data.title: [Feature Request] Support for low-latency remote development
data.body:
Hi,

Common scenario is to have my workstation in my office, but when travelling or working from home, I would like to have a low latency editing experience. Today I do it through RDP what is quite slow...

Facebook engineers seem to be pretty happy with Nuclide approach:
https://nuclide.io/docs/features/remote/

Thanks

data.title: Markdown (.md) preview (CTRL+SHIFT+v) not working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.0 (9122ec4b1068bd391e41974f46a4b54c1b9c90f9, 2017-04-05T20:59:05.375Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-instant-markdown|dbankier|1.1.0|
|bower|donjayamanne|0.0.3|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0|
|vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.1.8|
|task-master|ianhoney|0.1.39|
|Angular1|johnpapa|0.1.16|
|Angular2|johnpapa|2.2.3|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.5|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.8.1|
|java|redhat|0.1.0|
|sharecode|RolandGreim|0.4.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open up a readme.md that may or may not have markdown syntax errors.
2. Try to preview via CTRL+SHIFT+V

Expected Results:
1. The Preview pane opens with a rendered edition of readme.md

Actual Results:
1. The Preview 'readme.md' opens up completely blank (no error message)
2. After a few seconds, a small window shows up on the far right with the words "Scripts have been disabled in this document".

data.title: NumLock/NumPad keys stopped working in 1.11 on Linux
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.0
- OS Version: Linux 4.9.20-1-lts (Arch Linux)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In vscode 1.11 try to use a numpad key to navigate in a file (e.g. left/right/up/down arrows, Home, End, PgUp, PgDn)

The default keybindings don't recognize the numpad keyboard keys anymore in v1.11 (they worked fine until 1.10). For example, the `cursorEnd` command is bound to the `End` keybinding by default, but I need to add `NumPad1` manually in order for the numpad End key to work as well.

I had to add these to `keybindings.json` in order to restore the old behavior:

```json
// Place your key bindings in this file to overwrite the defaults
[
    {
        "key": "numpad7",
        "command": "cursorHome",
        "when": "editorTextFocus"
    },
    {
        "key": "numpad1",
        "command": "cursorEnd",
        "when": "editorTextFocus"
    },
    {
        "key": "numpad8",
        "command": "cursorUp",
        "when": "editorTextFocus"
    },
    {
        "key": "numpad2",
        "command": "cursorDown",
        "when": "editorTextFocus"
    },
    {
        "key": "numpad4",
        "command": "cursorLeft",
        "when": "editorTextFocus"
    },
    {
        "key": "numpad6",
        "command": "cursorRight",
        "when": "editorTextFocus"
    },
    {
        "key": "numpad9",
        "command": "cursorPageUp",
        "when": "editorTextFocus"
    },
    {
        "key": "numpad3",
        "command": "cursorPageDown",
        "when": "editorTextFocus"
    }
]
```

data.title: There should still be a command to go to the JSON view of keybindings
data.body:
With the new keybindings UI, the ability to jump directly to the keybindings JSON view is lost.
There should be a new command to bind to jump directly to the JSON view.

data.title: April Issue Grooming - review, categorization, assignment
data.body:
During April we want to get the bug count down. As a first step we will review the assigned issues. During the review pass please make sure to:

- close obsolete/fixed issues
- each issue needs a **type** label, that is one of: `Bug`, `Feature-Request`, `Debt`, `Needs more Info`, `Question`, `Under-Discussion`, `upstream`:
  - Bug - the implementation of a feature is not correct
  - Feature-Request - request to change the proper implementation of a feature or a request for a new feature that needs to be implemented.
  - Under Discussion - not decided whether the issue is a bug or feature
  - Debt - improve the implementation/architecture
  - Needs more info - not possible to assing a type label due to missing information
  - Question - we should direct questions to SO
  - upstream - an issue used to track an issue in an upstream component
  - **Note**: All type labels are grey (Bugs grey with a touch of red).
- assign the `important` label to issues that
  -  result in data loss
  - a breakage of extension
  - critical security, performance issues
  - UI issue that makes a feature unusable
- each issue needs to be assigned to a [feature area](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Feature-Areas)
- assign bugs that you plan to fix during April to the April milestone
- issues that the community can take up should be labeled as `help-wanted`
- feature requests that should be implemented as extensions should be labeled `extensions-candidate` and be closed

### Finding issues with no Type label
Use the following filter an replace the assignee:
```
is:open is:issue -label:bug -label:feature-request -label:debt -label:under-discussion assignee:YOURNAME -label:question -label:upstream -label:plan-item -label:"needs more info"
```

## Tracking:

Please make sure that you also do this grooming in our satellite repositories:
  - [x] @alexandrudima (done in vscode, not done in monaco-editor)
  - [x] @weinand
  - [x] @chrmarti
  - [x] @tyriar
  - [ ] @dbaeumer
  - [x] @bpasero
  - [x] @egamma
  - [x] @isidorn
  - [ ] @joaomoreno
  - [x] @jrieken
  - [x] @kieferrm
  - [ ] @aeschli
  - [x] @rebornix
  - [x] @ramya-rao-a
  - [x] @roblourens
  - [x] @sandy081
  - [x] @mjbvz
  - [x] @mousetraps
  - [x] @michelkaporin

data.title: French AZERTY keyboard layout: Fold/unfold defaut keymaps broken on OSX
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:1.11.0 
- OS Version: OSX Sierra 10.12.4 (16E195

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Using a mac book pro with a french azerty keyboard (or at least using the French input source in osx keyboard settings I don't have a non french mac at hand to verify this)
2. open a file with foldable sections
3. try to fold a section with the default shortcuts. 

On a French AZERTY mac keyboard, there is no `[` key. Typing a `[` requires one to press `(`. 

Since `[`(`alt+cmd+[`) is impossible to type, I tried :
* `(` doesn't do anything
*  `(` doesn't do anything

I then tried to edit the keybindings to add these combinations to editor.fold (and the matching ones for editor.unfold) but these functions are not available in the `keyboard shortcuts` editor.

I had to define 
```
    { "key": "alt+cmd+5",           "command": "editor.fold", "when": "editorTextFocus" },
    { "key": "alt+cmd+[Minus]",           "command": "editor.unfold", "when": "editorTextFocus" }
```
in keybindings.json to get folding to work.

I was able to find the right key combinations thanks to a combo of the blue information icon which tells me which keys I am supposed to press in my layout and the `K K`feature to reverse match various key presses to the corresponding codes.

Unfortunately it seems the "define keybinding" ( `K K` ) box is unable to find the right key combination to produce the default mapping's code. 

According to the box `^` is equivalent to `alt+cmd+[BracketLeft]` which sounds like the right code for `[` but event after I removed my overrides I was unable to get the folding to work pressing `^` and `$`

Since the editor is already capable of translating  keypresses into the corresponding keycodes, it would be very very useful if there was a way to get with all the existing shortcut expressed in the current user's layout. 
It would also be great if the default keymap included a working shortcut for fold/unfold on non qwerty keyboards.

![img_20170406_144928](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22979/24755211/983ecc2a-1ad9-11e7-9c93-a902539d70df.jpg)

data.title: ** in search.exclude glob should work the same way it did before
data.body:
**Edit:** One of my exclusion globs [was not valid.](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/24050#issuecomment-292257635) `"**/**$$*.java": true` should be changed to `"**/*$$*.java": true`

- VSCode Version: 1.11
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open global search and enter a query
2. No results found
3. Open a file you know contains a result for that query
4. Search again, results from that file now show up
5. In `settings.json` set `"search.useRipgrep": false`
6. Search again, results from all files now show.

<details>
<summary>My `settings.json`</summary>

```json
{
  "window.zoomLevel": 0,
  "window.newWindowDimensions": "maximized",

  "editor.rulers": [80, 120],
  "editor.renderIndentGuides": true,
  "editor.renderWhitespace": "boundary",
  "editor.renderControlCharacters": true,
  "editor.scrollBeyondLastLine": false,
  "editor.trimAutoWhitespace": true,
  "editor.fontFamily": "FiraCode-Regular",
  "editor.fontLigatures": true,

  "files.hotExit": "onExitAndWindowClose",
  "files.exclude": {
    "**/.git": true,
    "**/.svn": true,
    "**/.hg": true,
    "**/.DS_Store": true,
    "**/*.class": true,
    "**/**$$*.java": true,
    "**/.gradle/**": true,
    "**/.idea/*": true,
    "**/*.dSYM.zip": true,
    "**/*.ipa": true,
    "**/*.jks": true
  },
  "files.associations": {
    "Fastfile": "ruby",
    "Appfile": "ruby",
    "Podfile": "ruby",
    "*.apib": "markdown"
  },

  "search.exclude": {
    "**/node_modules": true,
    "**/bower_components": true,
    "**/dist": true,
    "**/coverage": true
  },

  "typescript.check.tscVersion": false,
  "editor.wordWrap": true,
  "workbench.colorTheme": "One Dark",
  "workbench.iconTheme": "vs-seti",

  "gitlens.blame.annotation.activeLine": "hover",
  "gitlens.statusBar.enabled": true,
  "gitlens.codeLens.location": "custom",
  "search.useRipgrep": false
}
</details>

data.title: JS autocomplete (suggestions) work wrong
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.0 (9122ec4b1068bd391e41974f46a4b54c1b9c90f9, 2017-04-05T20:52:01.201Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.3.0
- Extensions: the listing exceeds the lower minimum of browsers' URL characters limit
---

Steps to Reproduce:


I want to write `console.log` => `log` or `cl`. Instead, I got this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2588730/24750085/4439c824-1ace-11e7-860b-5714ddd2de83.png)

Always in autocomplete inside `.vue`-files I got wrong suggestions from a .css files: https://pp.userapi.com/c638629/v638629408/ccb5/AyYOnKIyQi0.jpg
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2588730/24755468/0171ef7a-1ae3-11e7-9965-0164bd1fc1d9.png)

This behavior is most annoying in Visual Code. It can be fixed?

data.title: Enhancement Request - 'Alt+Down' step over collapsed content

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
**Version:** Version 1.5.2 **See the below code.** ```

A title I would like to move quickly over the collapsed section of code.

[+]
``` I would like to request that when selecting and moving a section of code with 'Alt+Down' that it steps over collapsed code blocks rather than expanding and stepping through line by line.

data.title: Bug: Commenting code in JSX files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.0 (9122ec4b1068bd391e41974f46a4b54c1b9c90f9, 2017-04-05T20:59:05.375Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.1.0|
|jsrefactor|cmstead|1.0.2|
|vscode-svgviewer|cssho|1.4.0|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0|
|docthis|joelday|0.4.3|
|Runner|mattn|0.1.14|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.5.1|
|vscode-flow|rtorr|276.3.0|
|stylelint|shinnn|0.23.0|
|vscode-react-native|vsmobile|0.3.2|
|quokka-vscode|WallabyJs|1.0.25|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open JavasScript file and select few lines to comment out
2. Press shortcut to comment code (ctr + /)
3. Commented code is with `/* multiline code */` instead of `// every line`

Expected behavior: Put `//` on beginning of every line as it's probably most standard way of commenting in every IDE.

Update: Seems like it's randomly switching between // and /**/ comment styles.

data.title: Ugly Editor Bug with typing
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11
- OS Version: CentOs Linux 7

Steps to Reproduce:
Behaviour occurs after update to version 1.11

1. Create a JavaScript file
2. Create an object  with array:  
var test = { 
     items: [{
        xtype: 'fieldcontainer',
        itemId: 'rangesContainer',
        fieldLabel: 'E',
        shrinkWrap: false
       }
    ]
}
`
3. Type a letter after E in fieldLabel. 
=> After a short delay, the cursor jumps to the end of the line behind the comma.

With this behaviour it is not possible to type fluently, because typing contiues after the comma.

data.title: Tab tooltip changes depending on whether text is hovered over or the outside of the tab
data.body: - VSCode Version: Code 1.11.0 (9122ec4b1068bd391e41974f46a4b54c1b9c90f9, 2017-04-05T20:52:01.201Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0 - Extensions: |Extension|Author|Version| |---|---|---| |material-icon-theme|PKief|2.0.3| |githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0| |php-intellisense|felixfbecker|1.1.4| |vscode-colorize|kamikillerto|0.4.0| |ftp-sync|lukasz-wronski|0.3.2| |typescript-javascript-grammar|ms-vscode|0.0.18| |language-stylus|sysoev|1.6.0| |twig|whatwedo|1.0.2| |Material-theme|zhuangtongfa|2.3.5|; --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. Hover over the text inside the tab, this gives you a tooltip with a file directory such as /Users/username/Desktop 2. Now hover over the very top part of the tab just before the edge of the tab. It now gives a toolip such as ~/Desktop Basically two different types of displaying the file path are given depending on whether you hover over the text inside the tab or the tab itself. Both the file paths are correct but the one that appears on the the tab itself rather than hovering over the text, is more succinct. The first screenshot shows hovering over the edge of the tab. The second screenshot shows hovering over the text inside the tab. You can't see the cursor location on the screenshots, but you can see the tooltip provided.
